conclusion: Plan to analyze the circuit using Kirchhoff's laws to determine voltage between points a and b when switch is closed.
Circuit with a voltmeter, two resistors (10 Ω and 20 Ω), a battery, and a switch (S). Voltmeter connected across the 10 Ω resistor. Includes resistance labeled R.
When switch S is open, voltmeter reads 6V, indicating voltage across 10 Ω resistor is 6V.
Circuit is a series-parallel combination; 10 Ω and 20 Ω resistors are in parallel with the voltmeter, entire circuit in series with battery.
When switch S is closed, 10 Ω and 20 Ω resistors are in parallel with voltmeter, forming a single equivalent resistance in series with battery.
Voltage across 10 Ω resistor when S is open is 6V, meaning entire battery voltage is divided between 10 Ω and 20 Ω resistors.
Using voltage divider rule, voltage across 10 Ω resistor (V1) is V × (10/30) = 6V.
Since voltmeter reads 6V when S is open, voltage between points a and b when S is closed will also be 6V.
